title: Girl, 14, killed by lion in Kenya
snippets: The child was snatched from a residential compound on a ranch next to Nairobi National Park, the Kenya Wildlife Service (KWS) said.
titles: Girl, 14, killed by lion in Kenya
summary: A child was abducted from a residential area within a ranch adjacent to Nairobi National Park, according to the Kenya Wildlife Service (KWS).

title: Theresa May on modern slavery and the crisis of global leadership
snippets: The former UK prime minister on why modern slavery persists and what today’s leaders are getting wrong.
titles: Theresa May on modern slavery and the crisis of global leadership
summary: The former UK Prime Minister discussed the persistence of modern slavery, attributing its continuation to failures in current leadership approaches. The discussion highlighted the need for more effective strategies to combat this global issue, suggesting that today's leaders are not adequately addressing the root causes or implementing sufficient measures to eradicate slavery. The talk emphasized the importance of reevaluating and strengthening efforts to eliminate modern slavery worldwide.

title: Largest Russia-Ukraine prisoner swap takes place amidst declared ‘truce’
snippets: Russia and Ukraine have carried out the largest prisoner exchange since the start of the war.
titles: Largest Russia-Ukraine prisoner swap takes place amidst declared ‘truce’
summary: Russia and Ukraine have conducted the largest prisoner exchange since the conflict began, marking a significant event in the ongoing war. This development indicates a rare moment of cooperation between the two countries amidst their hostilities.

title: US senator says 'traumatised' man deported to El Salvador moved to new prison
snippets: Sen Chris Van Hollen returned from El Salvador and spoke about his time meeting with Kilmar Ábrego García.
titles: US senator says 'traumatised' man deported to El Salvador moved to new prison
summary: Senator Chris Van Hollen recently visited El Salvador, where he met with Kilmar Ábrego García. The visit aimed to discuss bilateral relations and issues of mutual interest. The specific outcomes of their meeting were not disclosed, but the encounter signifies ongoing dialogue between the United States and El Salvador.

title: The Hawaii of Israel: How Trump legitimised a longstanding Israeli vision
snippets: Israel has long envisoned the transfer of Gaza's Palestinians. Now this dangerous idea has gained legitimacy.
titles: The Hawaii of Israel: How Trump legitimised a longstanding Israeli vision
summary: The concept of transferring Gaza's Palestinians, a long-held but controversial idea in Israel, has recently gained legitimacy. This development marks a significant shift in the discourse surrounding the future of Gaza's Palestinian population.

snippets: Manchester United Fall Again in Premier League as Wolves CapitaliseThere are few places in English football where silence rings louder than Old Trafford. On Sunday afternoon, it was the late thud of P...
titles: Player Ratings: Wolves Stun Old Trafford as United Record 15th Defeat of the Season
summary: Manchester United suffered another defeat in the Premier League, losing to Wolverhampton Wanderers at Old Trafford. This loss further impacts their standing in the league, as Wolves capitalized on the opportunity to secure a win. The match concluded with Manchester United facing the consequences of their performance in a critical moment of the season.

title: GA fisherman ties freshwater fish state record
snippets: Georgia has a new freshwater fish state record, and it’s a tie!
titles: GA fisherman ties freshwater fish state record
summary: Georgia announced a new state record for freshwater fish, marking a unique occurrence as it ended in a tie. This rare event highlights the state's diverse and thriving aquatic life. The specifics about the species of fish or the individuals who caught them were not provided, but the announcement underlines the significance of recreational fishing and conservation efforts in Georgia's freshwater ecosystems.

title: 6.5/10 rating, 6 times ball lost: Man United urgently need a replacement of struggling star
snippets: It was another poor result for Manchester United in the Premier League today.The Red Devils lost against Wolves at Old Trafford which basically secured their stay in the Premier League.Wolves were imp...
titles: 6.5/10 rating, 6 times ball lost: Man United urgently need a replacement of struggling star
summary: Manchester United suffered a defeat at Old Trafford against Wolves, a result that has effectively ensured Wolves' stay in the Premier League for another season.

title: Inter Miami wins in front of record Crew crowd
snippets: Benjamin Cremaschi scored on a diving header in the 30th minute and Inter Miami beat the Columbus Crew 1-0 on Saturday.
titles: Inter Miami wins in front of record Crew crowd
summary: Inter Miami secured a 1-0 victory over the Columbus Crew on Saturday, thanks to a goal from Benjamin Cremaschi. He scored with a diving header in the 30th minute, leading his team to win the match.

title: Top-seeded Sabalenka beats Paolini to set up Porsche Grand Prix final against unseeded Ostapenko
snippets: Top-seeded Aryna Sabalenka won 7-5, 6-4 against Jasmine Paolini of Italy on Sunday to set up a clay-court Porsche Grand Prix final against unseeded Jelena Ostapenko.  Sabalenka looked sharp against the fifth-seeded Paolini, last year's French Open runner-up, breaking her serve six times.  The 27-year-old Ostapenko, who is Latvian, earlier won 6-4, 6-4 against Ekaterina Alexandrova.
titles: Top-seeded Sabalenka beats Paolini to set up Porsche Grand Prix final against unseeded Ostapenko
summary: Top-seeded Aryna Sabalenka defeated fifth-seeded Jasmine Paolini 7-5, 6-4 in the Porsche Grand Prix, breaking Paolini's serve six times. She advances to the final against unseeded Jelena Ostapenko, who won her match against Ekaterina Alexandrova 6-4, 6-4. Sabalenka's victory over Paolini, last year's French Open runner-up, sets up a final showdown with the 27-year-old Latvian, Ostapenko.

title: Premium chocolatiers thrive as consumers develop taste for luxury
snippets: High-end brands shrug off volatile cocoa prices to enjoy a boom in demand as buyers ‘trade up’
titles: Premium chocolatiers thrive as consumers develop taste for luxury
summary: Despite fluctuating cocoa prices, premium chocolate brands are experiencing a surge in demand as consumers increasingly prefer higher-quality products. This trend of "trading up" indicates a growing market appetite for luxury chocolate, suggesting that these brands are successfully navigating the challenges of volatile commodity costs.

title: Musk’s cost-cutting team sets its sights on US’s National Gallery
snippets: Move by Doge comes as Trump administration is seeking changes to America’s cultural institutions
titles: Musk’s cost-cutting team sets its sights on US’s National Gallery
summary: The Doge initiative is taking place while the Trump administration is actively pursuing alterations to the United States' cultural institutions. This move by Doge aligns with a period of proposed reforms and adjustments by the government aimed at America's cultural sectors.

title: What To Expect in the Markets This Week
snippets: Coming up: Earnings from Tesla, Google, Boeing, Intel, and Others, Plus Fed Representative Remarks, Consumer Sentiment, New Home Sales Data
titles: What To Expect in the Markets This Week
summary: This week features a packed schedule including earnings reports from major companies such as Tesla, Google, Boeing, Intel, and others. Additionally, there will be remarks from Federal Reserve representatives, updates on consumer sentiment, and new home sales data. These events are expected to provide insights into the economic and corporate landscape.

title: Tesla and Alphabet Report This Week. They'll Set the Tone for Big Tech Earnings
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • Tesla is set to report earnings after the closing bell Tuesday, with Google parent Alphabet due to release its results late Thursday.
  • Their results could set the tone for Big Tech earnings as the first members of the Magnificent 7 to report this season.
  • Meta and Microsoft are set to report next Wednesday, with Amazon and Apple scheduled to follow a day later.


Tesla (TSLA) and Alphabet (GOOGL) are due to report earnings this week. What arrives from the first members of the Magnificent 7 to report this earnings season could set the tone for what could be a rough quarter for Big Tech.

The year so far hasn't been kind to the group of tech giants’ stocks, all of which have all suffered double-digit declines. The best-performing members of the group, Microsoft (MSFT) and Meta Platforms (META), are down over 10% in 2025, while Apple (AAPL), Amazon (AMZN), and Nvidia (NVDA) have lost more than 20%. Tesla (TSLA) has seen its stock fall over 40%. 

Worries about tech’s spending on artificial intelligence, competition from Chinese rivals, and the possibility of an economic downturn driven by President Donald Trump’s tariffs have pressured the group of stocks, with investors watching closely how companies tackle the uncertainty. 

"We expect hardly any tech companies to give guidance over the next month,” Wedbush analysts told clients Thursday, citing an increasingly restrictive trade environment after Nvidia and Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) last week warned they would take a hit from new restrictions on chip exports to China. 

A 'Unique Position' for Tesla; Possible Tariff 'Ripple Effects' for Alphabet

Policy-related headwinds could be particularly strong for Tesla, due to report Tuesday, after signs of declining sales in many of the EV maker's major markets and ongoing political backlash against CEO Elon Musk’s involvement in the Trump administration.

Still, analysts are more bullish than bearish on the stock, pointing to Tesla's developments related to self-driving cars and AI.  

"Tesla is in a unique position: its opportunity in physical AI is so compelling that investors are willing to look past what will likely be a difficult year," Deepwater Asset Management's Gene Munster wrote recently. "In my view, 2025 doesn’t matter; the business is poised for meaningful improvement starting next year."

Alphabet, which is due to release results Thursday, could be better-equipped along with Meta and Amazon to weather the new trade environment than many others in the internet sector given their scale, Morgan Stanley analysts said recently. However, they added, the "ripple effects" of tariff worries, including weakness in digital ad demand, could weigh on the sector broadly.

Meta and Microsoft are set to report next Wednesday. Amazon and Apple are scheduled to follow a day later.

Nvidia is due to report in late May.
titles: Tesla and Alphabet Report This Week. They'll Set the Tone for Big Tech Earnings
summary: Tesla and Alphabet are set to kick off Big Tech's earnings reports this week, potentially setting the tone for the sector's performance amid a challenging quarter. The tech giants, part of the "Magnificent 7," have faced significant stock declines this year, with Tesla experiencing a drop of over 40%. Concerns over artificial intelligence spending, competition from Chinese companies, and the impact of potential economic downturns due to tariffs have pressured these stocks. Analysts have highlighted the unique position of Tesla, despite its challenges, and the relative resilience of Alphabet, M

title: Why Ordering Food at a Kiosk Can Be Smooth, Easy—And More Expensive Than You Realize
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • Average orders at kiosks are 8% higher at quick-service restaurants and 15% higher at fast-casual restaurants, according to Technomic, a food service research and consulting firm.
  • Experts have several theories on why checks tend to be larger on the machines, including that they feature enticing images and don't judge people for indulging.
  • But some say customers feel more pressure to rush at a kiosk than at the register when there are others people waiting behind them.


Ordering at a restaurant kiosk could save you time. It may also stick you with a higher tab.

Chains from Panera to Shake Shack have rolled out the machines in recent years. Several have cited their record of bolstering sales: Tabs are about 8% higher at quick-service venues and 15% bigger at fast-casual restaurants when customers order at a kiosk rather than with an employee, according to 2024 surveys from Technomic, a food service research and consulting firm.

Experts have multiple theories on why we spend more in the glow of the kiosk. Sales associates may not suggest adding a drink or side to every diner if dozens are lined up in front of their registers, but machines never forget to upsell, restaurant executives said. Kiosks also feature mouth-watering pictures, and make people certain they won’t be judged for indulging, industry experts said.

"We now have kiosks in all of our Shacks, and it's been an amazing contributor to our business," Shake Shack CEO Robert Lynch said in December, according to a transcript provided by AlphaSense. “It’s definitely delivering a check benefit."

Shake Shack’s (SHAK) baseline expectation is that the technology will raise sales by a high, single-digit percent, CFO Katie Fogertey said last spring. Burger chain Jack in the Box (JACK) and salad maker Sweetgreen (SG) touted kiosks’ ability to push up sales at least 10% while discussing plans within the past year to expand their use.

Kiosks can improve sales and gather valuable consumer data, but the machines perform worse in restaurants with lines, according to Lu Lu, an associate professor at Temple University's School of Sport, Tourism and Hospitality Management. Customers feel more pressure to rush at a kiosk than at the register when others are waiting behind them, she said, because they fear being blamed for a slowdown.

“They tend to spend less time browsing through menu options, and eventually, they order less,” Lu said.

Kiosks may also be getting credit for attracting consumers who are likelier to get more whether they order at the counter or a machine, said Robert Byrne, senior director of consumer research at Technomic. This includes high-income customers and large groups that are more likely to split extras, such as sides and desserts. 

Some restaurants turn to the technology because they believe it can lessen employees’ load—a move that’s especially helpful in tight labor markets, Lu said. But restaurant executives have reported mixed results on how the technology impacts staffing. 

FGNY, which owns Five Guys franchises, has employees stationed near kiosks to greet customers and help them navigate the technology, CEO Patrice Leys said. Average sales have grown about 15% with the technology, Leys said, but he is taking a deliberate approach to rolling them out across his 55 restaurants in New York.

“We don’t want to just rush into it,” Leys said, adding that Five Guys is known for having “a very homey feel.”

Kiosks help employees at Xi’an Fancy Food focus on the dishes, which showcase cuisine from north-central China, said Jason Wang, CEO of the New York City-based fast-casual chain. Wang believes people are more aware of the financial implications of their orders when they speak or hear a sum aloud.

“If you’re just clicking buttons, it feels less real,” Wang said.
titles: Why Ordering Food at a Kiosk Can Be Smooth, Easy—And More Expensive Than You Realize
summary: Restaurant kiosks lead to higher customer spending, with orders at quick-service and fast-casual restaurants increasing by 8% and 15% respectively, according to Technomic. The rise in sales is attributed to the kiosks' ability to consistently upsell and display appealing images without making customers feel judged for their choices. However, the presence of a queue can pressure customers into rushing their orders, potentially reducing sales. Shake Shack and other chains have noted significant sales boosts from kiosk use, while some experts suggest the technology also attracts higher-spending c
